content:
I have no guess. I do not have this problem in 145.0.

A standard troubleshooting method is to start Windows in safe mode with networking, then start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode (help menu), and see if the problem still occurs.

content: I find nothing in your prior posts that describes a problem. For any assistance, please provide information on the problem you encountered, error messages, and setup., Yes, install TB and set up an account and then advise of whatever the issue is. If there are problems, include a screenshot of the incoming server settings pane and the SMTP server settings pane and full text of any error messages. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content:
Your PW needs to be a generated app PW - see https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN15241.html.

Settings:

IMAP - Server Name: export.imap.mail.yahoo.com - Port: 993 - Connection Security: SSL/TLS - Authentication method: Normal password

SMTP - Server Name: smtp.mail.yahoo.com - Port: 587 - Connection Security: SSL/TLS - Authentication method: Normal password
creator: siffemoz

content:
Thank-you, Ed.

Ed said
Your PW needs to be a generated app PW - see https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN15241.html.

yahoo requires me to log in to the e-mail account to get that "app PW". I tried that via Firefox on the same new desktop as the Thunderbird in which I'm trying to add the e-mail account. yahoo rejected the login with no reason given. I used the little eye icon so I could see the password that I entered, and it was correct. I assume that if I entered the password incorrectly in that Firefox browser login, yahoo would ask me to try the login again, not reject me after one try.

Can the Firefox login for the "app password" and the Thunderbird in which I'm trying to add the account be different desktops with different operating systems? or do they have to be the same desktop and operating system? The Thunderbird on my old windows-10 desktop has the yahoo e-mail account working fine (at the moment!).

1. I see that when I go to the yahoo page that you referenced, when I look at yahoo's instructions, it says: "When creating an app password, use a browser that you've used to sign into Yahoo for several days in a row and avoid using Incognito mode." 2. The yahoo e-mail account works fine in Thunderbird on the old desktop. On the old desktop, using Firefox, I can login to the yahoo e-mail account. But on the new desktop, neither approach works. 3. I've seen many times that yahoo knows which client and operating system I'm using to access my e-mail account. It seems to me that, logically, what's causing the problem is that I'm trying to access my yahoo e-mail from a client-OS combination that I've never used before.

How much of a chance does this have of working: 1. I generate the "app password" on the old desktop. 2. I shut down the old desktop, crawl around on the floor under the desk and table to switch cables around, and power up the new desktop. 3. On the new desktop, I try to create the yahoo e-mail account using the "app password" that was generated on the old desktop. This will take significant time and effort, so I'd like to know it has a good chance of working before I try it. Also, question: does the new "app password" go into the password field in the page I use to create the new account, the password table in settings, or both?

the "forgot password thing": I learned the hard way the there is serious vulnerability in saved passwords and password managers; I seriously avoid those. I'm drowning in passwords that I manually enter. I'd like to avoid changing my password until a last resort.

I do not have an "app password" for the e-mail account on the old desktop.
creator: mattison_moz

content:
It sounds like the issue is likely related to Yahoo blocking less-secure apps or Thunderbird needing an app-specific password for IMAP. Here’s what you can try:

Go to your Yahoo account Security settings and enable “Allow apps that use less secure sign-in” (if available).

If you have 2-step verification enabled, generate an App Password specifically for Thunderbird and use that instead of your regular Yahoo password.

Make sure Thunderbird is fully updated, and choose OAuth2 as the authentication method when adding your account.

This approach is similar to how reliable workflows are crucial in other fields — for example, in styled shots for clothing brand , using proper credentials and verified processes ensures smooth and error-free operations.
creator: ryan.mitchell1184

content:
This:

"1. I generate the "app password" on the old desktop. 2. I shut down the old desktop, crawl around on the floor under the desk and table to switch cables around, and power up the new desktop. 3. On the new desktop, I try to create the yahoo e-mail account using the "app password" that was generated on the old desktop."

worked, in this case.

For some of my e-mail accounts, I needed to do the above. For other e-mail accounts, I did not. I do not know why it varied from one e-mail coount to another.

For any yahoo e-mail programmers/managers that might see this, this thread's issue has me seriously concerned. Not only did I have trouble adding a yahoo account to Thunderbird on a new desktop, I was also blocked logging into my yahoo e-mail in a browser on the new desktop. If I had only one desktop and no other way of accessing e-mail, and the desktop suddenly failed, I'd get a new desktop. But then how would I access my yahoo e-mail? A change in e-mail client or operating system, or even hardware, would totally block me. Security is very important. But it can be taken too far.

Ed: I thank you for your replies. They did help. They got me thinking in a way that led to the solution.
creator: mattison_moz

content:
> I guess you could try to re-add it.

Before I spend a bunch of time and effort on that...

Every time I try to do the settings for a yahoo account that I'm trying to add, PER INSTRUCTIONS, I try to set the outgoing port to 587 AND the connection security to SSL/TLS. Thunderbird does not allow me to do that. - If I set the port to 587, Thunderbird sets or changes the connection security to STARTTLS. - If I set the connection security to SSL/TLS, Thunderbird sets or changes the port to 465.

What are the correct outgoing settings?
creator: mattison_moz

content:
home user said
> I guess you could try to re-add it. Before I spend a bunch of time and effort on that... Every time I try to do the settings for a yahoo account that I'm trying to add, PER INSTRUCTIONS, I try to set the outgoing port to 587 AND the connection security to SSL/TLS. Thunderbird does not allow me to do that. - If I set the port to 587, Thunderbird sets or changes the connection security to STARTTLS. - If I set the connection security to SSL/TLS, Thunderbird sets or changes the port to 465. What are the correct outgoing settings?

465, because SSL is required.
creator: siffemoz

content:
Last night, I finally got all the yahoo e-mail accounts working in Thunderbird on the new desktop (Linux). I finished verifying a short while ago. The sending messages took more time and effort to get right than connection and receiving.

I do not know what goes on "under the hood". But cookies seemed to matter. What is and is not in the password table (Settings -> Privacy & Security -> Saved Passwords) seemed to matter. Until the account adding is truly complete, when sending a message, manual entry of passwords in the Thunderbird password entry GUI must be quick. Something's memory: yahoo's? Thunderbird's? Firefox's? the OS or the file system's? also seems to matter. After changing something, it seems to sometimes take a while, or even need to quit and re-launch, or even a reboot, for the change to "kick in".

I thank Ed for his help. I believe this really is solved now.
creator: mattison_moz
